Class EyeModel_

  • java.lang.Object
    • EyeModel_
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ij.plugin.PlugIn

    public class EyeModel_
extends java.lang.Object
implements ij.plugin.PlugIn
    ImageJ plugin to calculate eye frequency response using either Richard and Siewerdsen 2008, http://dx.doi.org/10.1118/1.2988161:

    E(f) = fn.exp(-c.f2) 
    
 where f = radial spatial frequency (mm-1)
       n = 1.3
       c = 3.093 for a 50 cm viewing distance for E(f) to peak at 4 degree-1
    or Solomon et al 2015, http://dx.doi.org/10.1118/1.4923172:

    E(ρ) = |n.ρa1.exp(-a2.ρa3)|2 
    
 where a1 = 1.5
       a2 = 0.98
       a3 = 0.68
       n is a normalisation constant to make max E(ρ) = 1.0
       ρ is angular spatial frequency (degree-1)

 ρ can be calculated from radial spatial frequency using:

 ρ = (f.FOV.R.π) / (D.180)

 where f is radial spatial frequency (mm-1)
       FOV is the reconstructed field of view of the image (mm)
       R is the viewing distance (mm)
       D is the display size (mm) (assumed to be 305 mm in the Solomon paper)
       Note to self: is D the physical size of the full image as displayed on the screen?
                     If so, can calculate this if know the pixel pitch in mm, the pixel
                     dimensions of the image and the zoom factor... this is what ImaQuest asks for


    The Solomon et al 2015 option is mathematically the same as that used by the Imquest software Eckstein option. The original Eckstein work did not normalise the function, nor did it square the result (http://dx.doi.org/10.1364/OE.11.000460).

      • calc_f_to_rho_factor

        private double calc_f_to_rho_factor()
        Method to calculate the conversion from radial frequency (per mm) to angular frequency (cycles per degree). This method uses equation 4 in http://dx.doi.org/10.1118/1.4923172 to calculate this factor:

        ρ = r.FOV.R.π / (D.180) 
         where:
     ρ   is angular spatial frequency (degree-1)
     r   is radial spatial frequency in (mm-1)
     FOV is the reconstructed field of view of the image (mm)
     R   is the viewing distance (mm)
     D   is the display size (mm) (I'm assuming this is the physical size of the image on the display)
        This method calculates FOV.R.π / (D.180), so that values of radial frequency can be multiplied by this factor to obtain values of angular spatial frequency.
        Returns:
        The conversion factor

      • calc_displayed_image_size

        private double calc_displayed_image_size()
        Method to calculate the displayed image size from the display pixel pitch, the pixel width of the image and the display zoom factor.
        Returns:
        The conversion factor
